thread.title: H.S. football: Ridgewood fights through challenges, beats Clifton, 30-14 - Sports
thread.title_full: H.S. football: Ridgewood fights through challenges, beats Clifton, 30-14 - Sports - NorthJersey.com

author: JIM McCONVILLE
title: H.S. football: Ridgewood fights through challenges, beats Clifton, 30-14 - Sports
text:
RIDGEWOOD – On a night where the game was delayed by lightning for more than an hour and the lights went out in the third quarter, Ridgewood overcame all of the distractions as well as a couple of injuries to win an important game.
With a 30-14 defeat of previously unbeaten Clifton, the Maroons move to 4-1 on the season as they prepare for a three-game stretch where they face Paramus, Hackensack and Passaic Tech — all ranked in The Record public school Top 20.
“I thought we handled the distraction at the beginning of the game well,” Ridgewood coach Chuck Johnson said. “It’s always difficult to be geared up to go and you have to shut it down for that long.”
Ridgewood came out with a 13-play drive to a 23-yard field goal by Wylie Sherman and got the best of back-to-back turnovers to score again late in the first quarter.
A Maroon lost fumble was followed on the next play by an interception by Jack Kiernan, his first of two in the game. Three plays later, quarterback Griffin Peene went 59 yards on a keeper off the left side for a touchdown.
Austin Denise buried the Mustangs (2-1-1) at the 2-yard line with a punt and Kiernan returned the ensuing Clifton punt 22 yards to the Mustang 8. It set up Erik Bachrach for a 1-yard touchdown.
Bachrach made it 24-0 with just over 4 minutes left in the first half with a 31-yard scamper.
The Maroons scored off their first series of the third quarter, a 6-yarder by Peene, who paced the Ridgewood ground game with 10 carries for 114 yards. They were marching again when the lights went out with 3:05 left in the third.
The offense sputtered thanks to the delay, combined with injuries to Bachrach (collarbone) and fullback Coleston Smith (ankle).
Clifton had scored just before the lights went out on a 26-yard pass from Joe Santillo to Delano Dixon.
“That was a no quit performance,” Johnson said of the Mustangs. “That impressed me. They could have quit and they never did. [Clifton coach] Ralph [Cinque] deserves a lot of credit for the way that team is playing.”
Dixon and Santillo hooked up again in the fourth quarter with 1:52 left for a 4-yard TD pass.
